attributes.name: Ember
attributes.description:
This namespace contains all Ember methods and functions. Future versions of
Ember may overwrite this namespace and therefore, you should avoid adding any
new properties.

You can also use the shorthand `Em` instead of `Ember`.

At the heart of Ember is Ember-Runtime, a set of core functions that provide
cross-platform compatibility and object property observing.  Ember-Runtime is
small and performance-focused so you can use it alongside other
cross-platform libraries such as jQuery. For more details, see
[Ember-Runtime](http://emberjs.com/api/modules/ember-runtime.html).

methods.name: assert

params.name: desc
params.description:
A description of the assertion. This will become
  the text of the Error thrown if the assertion fails.

params.name: test
params.description:
Must be truthy for the assertion to pass. If
  falsy, an exception will be thrown. If this is a function, it will be executed and
  its return value will be used as condition.

methods.description:
Display a warning with the provided message. Ember build tools will
remove any calls to `Ember.warn()` when doing a production build.
methods.name: warn

params.name: message
params.description: A warning to display.

params.name: test
params.description:
An optional boolean. If falsy, the warning
  will be displayed.

methods.description:
Display a debug notice. Ember build tools will remove any calls to
`Ember.debug()` when doing a production build.

```javascript
Ember.debug('I\'m a debug notice!');
```
methods.name: debug

params.name: message
params.description: A debug message to display.

methods.description:
Display a deprecation warning with the provided message and a stack trace
(Chrome and Firefox only). Ember build tools will remove any calls to
`Ember.deprecate()` when doing a production build.
methods.name: deprecate

params.name: message
params.description: A description of the deprecation.

params.name: test
params.description:
An optional boolean. If falsy, the deprecation
  will be displayed. If this is a function, it will be executed and its return
  value will be used as condition.

params.name: options
params.description:
An optional object that can be used to pass
  in a `url` to the transition guide on the emberjs.com website, and a unique
  `id` for this deprecation. The `id` can be used by Ember debugging tools
  to change the behavior (raise, log or silence) for that specific deprecation.
  The `id` should be namespaced by dots, e.g. "view.helper.select".

methods.description:
Alias an old, deprecated method with its new counterpart.

Display a deprecation warning with the provided message and a stack trace
(Chrome and Firefox only) when the assigned method is called.

Ember build tools will not remove calls to `Ember.deprecateFunc()`, though
no warnings will be shown in production.

```javascript
Ember.oldMethod = Ember.deprecateFunc('Please use the new, updated method', Ember.newMethod);
```
methods.name: deprecateFunc

params.name: message
params.description: A description of the deprecation.

params.name: options
params.description: The options object for Ember.deprecate.

params.name: func
params.description: The new function called to replace its deprecated counterpart.

return.description: a new function that wrapped the original function with a deprecation warning

methods.name: runInDebug

params.name: func
params.description: The function to be executed.

methods.description:
Will call `Ember.warn()` if ENABLE_ALL_FEATURES, ENABLE_OPTIONAL_FEATURES, or
any specific FEATURES flag is truthy.

This method is called automatically in debug canary builds.
methods.name: _warnIfUsingStrippedFeatureFlags

methods.description:
Returns true if the provided path is global (e.g., `MyApp.fooController.bar`)
instead of local (`foo.bar.baz`).
methods.name: isGlobalPath

methods.description:
Global helper method to create a new binding. Just pass the root object
along with a `to` and `from` path to create and connect the binding.
methods.name: bind

params.name: obj
params.description: The root object of the transform.

params.name: to
params.description:
The path to the 'to' side of the binding.
  Must be relative to obj.

params.name: from
params.description:
The path to the 'from' side of the binding.
  Must be relative to obj or a global path.

methods.description:
Returns the cached value for a property, if one exists.
This can be useful for peeking at the value of a computed
property that is generated lazily, without accidentally causing
it to be created.
methods.name: cacheFor

params.name: obj
params.description: the object whose property you want to check

params.name: key
params.description:
the name of the property whose cached value you want
  to return

methods.description: An empty function useful for some operations. Always returns `this`.
methods.name: K

methods.description: Add an event listener
methods.name: addListener

params.name: target
params.description: A target object or a function

params.name: method
params.description: A function or the name of a function to be called on `target`

params.name: once
params.description: A flag whether a function should only be called once

methods.description:
Remove an event listener

Arguments should match those passed to `Ember.addListener`.
methods.name: removeListener

params.name: target
params.description: A target object or a function

params.name: method
params.description: A function or the name of a function to be called on `target`

methods.description:
Suspend listener during callback.

This should only be used by the target of the event listener
when it is taking an action that would cause the event, e.g.
an object might suspend its property change listener while it is
setting that property.
methods.name: suspendListener

params.name: target
params.description: A target object or a function

params.name: method
params.description: A function or the name of a function to be called on `target`

methods.description: Suspends multiple listeners during a callback.
methods.name: suspendListeners

params.name: eventNames
params.description: Array of event names

params.name: target
params.description: A target object or a function

params.name: method
params.description: A function or the name of a function to be called on `target`

methods.description: Return a list of currently watched events
methods.name: watchedEvents

methods.description:
Send an event. The execution of suspended listeners
is skipped, and once listeners are removed. A listener without
a target is executed on the passed object. If an array of actions
is not passed, the actions stored on the passed object are invoked.
methods.name: sendEvent

params.name: params
params.description: Optional parameters for each listener.

params.name: actions
params.description: Optional array of actions (listeners).

methods.name: on

methods.description:
Expands `pattern`, invoking `callback` for each expansion.

The only pattern supported is brace-expansion, anything else will be passed
once to `callback` directly.

Example

```js
function echo(arg){ console.log(arg); }

Ember.expandProperties('foo.bar', echo);              //=> 'foo.bar'
Ember.expandProperties('{foo,bar}', echo);            //=> 'foo', 'bar'
Ember.expandProperties('foo.{bar,baz}', echo);        //=> 'foo.bar', 'foo.baz'
Ember.expandProperties('{foo,bar}.baz', echo);        //=> 'foo.baz', 'bar.baz'
Ember.expandProperties('foo.{bar,baz}.[]', echo)   //=> 'foo.bar.[]', 'foo.baz.[]'
Ember.expandProperties('{foo,bar}.{spam,eggs}', echo) //=> 'foo.spam', 'foo.eggs', 'bar.spam', 'bar.eggs'
Ember.expandProperties('{foo}.bar.{baz}')             //=> 'foo.bar.baz'
```
methods.name: expandProperties

params.name: pattern
params.description: The property pattern to expand.

params.name: callback
params.description:
The callback to invoke.  It is invoked once per
expansion, and is passed the expansion.

methods.name: getProperties

params.name: list
params.description: of keys to get

methods.description:
A value is blank if it is empty or a whitespace string.

```javascript
Ember.isBlank();                // true
Ember.isBlank(null);            // true
Ember.isBlank(undefined);       // true
Ember.isBlank('');              // true
Ember.isBlank([]);              // true
Ember.isBlank('\n\t');          // true
Ember.isBlank('  ');            // true
Ember.isBlank({});              // false
Ember.isBlank('\n\t Hello');    // false
Ember.isBlank('Hello world');   // false
Ember.isBlank([1,2,3]);         // false
```
methods.name: isBlank

params.name: obj
params.description: Value to test

methods.description:
Verifies that a value is `null` or an empty string, empty array,
or empty function.

Constrains the rules on `Ember.isNone` by returning true for empty
string and empty arrays.

```javascript
Ember.isEmpty();                // true
Ember.isEmpty(null);            // true
Ember.isEmpty(undefined);       // true
Ember.isEmpty('');              // true
Ember.isEmpty([]);              // true
Ember.isEmpty({});              // false
Ember.isEmpty('Adam Hawkins');  // false
Ember.isEmpty([0,1,2]);         // false
```
methods.name: isEmpty

params.name: obj
params.description: Value to test

methods.description:
Returns true if the passed value is null or undefined. This avoids errors
from JSLint complaining about use of ==, which can be technically
confusing.

```javascript
Ember.isNone();              // true
Ember.isNone(null);          // true
Ember.isNone(undefined);     // true
Ember.isNone('');            // false
Ember.isNone([]);            // false
Ember.isNone(function() {});  // false
```
methods.name: isNone

params.name: obj
params.description: Value to test

methods.description:
A value is present if it not `isBlank`.

```javascript
Ember.isPresent();                // false
Ember.isPresent(null);            // false
Ember.isPresent(undefined);       // false
Ember.isPresent(false);           // false
Ember.isPresent('');              // false
Ember.isPresent([]);              // false
Ember.isPresent('\n\t');          // false
Ember.isPresent('  ');            // false
Ember.isPresent({});              // true
Ember.isPresent('\n\t Hello');    // true
Ember.isPresent('Hello world');   // true
Ember.isPresent([1,2,3]);         // true
```
methods.name: isPresent

params.name: obj
params.description: Value to test

methods.description:
Returns all of the keys defined on an object or hash. This is useful
when inspecting objects for debugging. On browsers that support it, this
uses the native `Object.keys` implementation.
methods.name: keys
merge

params.name: original
params.description: The object to merge into

params.name: updates
params.description: The object to copy properties from

methods.description: Denotes a required property for a mixin
methods.name: required
aliasMethod

params.name: methodName
params.description: name of the method to alias

methods.name: observer
_immediateObserver
beforeObserver
defineProperty

params.name: obj
params.description: the object to define this property on. This may be a prototype.

params.name: keyName
params.description: the name of the property

params.name: desc
params.description:
an instance of `Descriptor` (typically a
  computed property) or an ES5 descriptor.
  You must provide this or `data` but not both.

params.name: data
params.description:
something other than a descriptor, that will
  become the explicit value of this property.

methods.description:
This function is called just before an object property is about to change.
It will notify any before observers and prepare caches among other things.

Normally you will not need to call this method directly but if for some
reason you can't directly watch a property you can invoke this method
manually along with `Ember.propertyDidChange()` which you should call just
after the property value changes.
methods.name: propertyWillChange

params.name: obj
params.description: The object with the property that will change

params.name: keyName
params.description: The property key (or path) that will change.

methods.description:
This function is called just after an object property has changed.
It will notify any observers and clear caches among other things.

Normally you will not need to call this method directly but if for some
reason you can't directly watch a property you can invoke this method
manually along with `Ember.propertyWillChange()` which you should call just
before the property value changes.
methods.name: propertyDidChange

params.name: obj
params.description: The object with the property that will change

params.name: keyName
params.description: The property key (or path) that will change.

methods.name: changeProperties

methods.description:
Gets the value of a property on an object. If the property is computed,
the function will be invoked. If the property is not defined but the
object implements the `unknownProperty` method then that will be invoked.

If you plan to run on IE8 and older browsers then you should use this
method anytime you want to retrieve a property on an object that you don't
know for sure is private. (Properties beginning with an underscore '_'
are considered private.)

On all newer browsers, you only need to use this method to retrieve
properties if the property might not be defined on the object and you want
to respect the `unknownProperty` handler. Otherwise you can ignore this
method.

Note that if the object itself is `undefined`, this method will throw
an error.
methods.name: get

params.name: obj
params.description: The object to retrieve from.

params.name: keyName
params.description: The property key to retrieve

methods.description:
Normalizes a target/path pair to reflect that actual target/path that should
be observed, etc. This takes into account passing in global property
paths (i.e. a path beginning with a capital letter not defined on the
target).
methods.name: normalizeTuple

params.name: target
params.description: The current target. May be `null`.

params.name: path
params.description: A path on the target or a global property path.

return.description: a temporary array with the normalized target/path pair.

methods.description:
Sets the value of a property on an object, respecting computed properties
and notifying observers and other listeners of the change. If the
property is not defined but the object implements the `setUnknownProperty`
method then that will be invoked as well.
methods.name: set

params.name: obj
params.description: The object to modify.

params.name: keyName
params.description: The property key to set

params.name: value
params.description: The value to set

methods.description:
Error-tolerant form of `Ember.set`. Will not blow up if any part of the
chain is `undefined`, `null`, or destroyed.

This is primarily used when syncing bindings, which may try to update after
an object has been destroyed.
methods.name: trySet

params.name: root
params.description: The object to modify.

params.name: path
params.description: The property path to set

params.name: value
params.description: The value to set

methods.name: setProperties

methods.description:
Generates a new guid, optionally saving the guid to the object that you
pass in. You will rarely need to use this method. Instead you should
call `Ember.guidFor(obj)`, which return an existing guid if available.
methods.name: generateGuid

params.name: obj
params.description:
Object the guid will be used for. If passed in, the guid will
  be saved on the object and reused whenever you pass the same object
  again.

  If no object is passed, just generate a new guid.

params.name: prefix
params.description:
Prefix to place in front of the guid. Useful when you want to
  separate the guid into separate namespaces.

methods.description:
Returns a unique id for the object. If the object does not yet have a guid,
one will be assigned to it. You can call this on any object,
`Ember.Object`-based or not, but be aware that it will add a `_guid`
property.

You can also use this method on DOM Element objects.
methods.name: guidFor

params.name: obj
params.description: any object, string, number, Element, or primitive

return.description: the unique guid for this instance.

methods.description:
Retrieves the meta hash for an object. If `writable` is true ensures the
hash is writable for this object as well.

The meta object contains information about computed property descriptors as
well as any watched properties and other information. You generally will
not access this information directly but instead work with higher level
methods that manipulate this hash indirectly.
methods.name: meta

params.name: obj
params.description: The object to retrieve meta for

params.name: writable
params.description:
Pass `false` if you do not intend to modify
  the meta hash, allowing the method to avoid making an unnecessary copy.

return.description: the meta hash for an object

methods.description:
Wraps the passed function so that `this._super` will point to the superFunc
when the function is invoked. This is the primitive we use to implement
calls to super.
methods.name: wrap

params.name: func
params.description: The function to call

params.name: superFunc
params.description: The super function.

methods.description:
Checks to see if the `methodName` exists on the `obj`.

```javascript
var foo = { bar: function() { return 'bar'; }, baz: null };

Ember.canInvoke(foo, 'bar'); // true
Ember.canInvoke(foo, 'baz'); // false
Ember.canInvoke(foo, 'bat'); // false
```
methods.name: canInvoke

params.name: obj
params.description: The object to check for the method

params.name: methodName
params.description: The method name to check for

methods.description:
Checks to see if the `methodName` exists on the `obj`,
and if it does, invokes it with the arguments passed.

```javascript
var d = new Date('03/15/2013');

Ember.tryInvoke(d, 'getTime');              // 1363320000000
Ember.tryInvoke(d, 'setFullYear', [2014]);  // 1394856000000
Ember.tryInvoke(d, 'noSuchMethod', [2014]); // undefined
```
methods.name: tryInvoke

params.name: obj
params.description: The object to check for the method

params.name: methodName
params.description: The method name to check for

params.name: args
params.description: The arguments to pass to the method

return.description: the return value of the invoked method or undefined if it cannot be invoked

methods.description:
Forces the passed object to be part of an array. If the object is already
an array, it will return the object. Otherwise, it will add the object to
an array. If obj is `null` or `undefined`, it will return an empty array.

```javascript
Ember.makeArray();            // []
Ember.makeArray(null);        // []
Ember.makeArray(undefined);   // []
Ember.makeArray('lindsay');   // ['lindsay']
Ember.makeArray([1, 2, 42]);  // [1, 2, 42]

var controller = Ember.ArrayProxy.create({ content: [] });

Ember.makeArray(controller) === controller;  // true
```
methods.name: makeArray

params.name: obj
params.description: the object

methods.description:
Convenience method to inspect an object. This method will attempt to
convert the object into a useful string description.

It is a pretty simple implementation. If you want something more robust,
use something like JSDump: https://github.com/NV/jsDump
methods.name: inspect

params.name: obj
params.description: The object you want to inspect.

methods.description:
Starts watching a property on an object. Whenever the property changes,
invokes `Ember.propertyWillChange` and `Ember.propertyDidChange`. This is the
primitive used by observers and dependent keys; usually you will never call
this method directly but instead use higher level methods like
`Ember.addObserver()`
methods.name: watch

methods.description:
Tears down the meta on an object so that it can be garbage collected.
Multiple calls will have no effect.
methods.name: destroy

params.name: obj
params.description: the object to destroy

methods.description: Finds a controller instance.
methods.name: controllerFor

methods.description: Generates a controller factory
methods.name: generateControllerFactory

methods.description:
Generates and instantiates a controller.

The type of the generated controller factory is derived
from the context. If the context is an array an array controller
is generated, if an object, an object controller otherwise, a basic
controller is generated.
methods.name: generateController
onLoad

params.name: name
params.description: name of hook

params.name: callback
params.description: callback to be called

methods.description:
Called when an Ember.js package (e.g Ember.Application) has finished
loading. Triggers any callbacks registered for this event.
methods.name: runLoadHooks

params.name: name
params.description: name of hook

params.name: object
params.description: object to pass to callbacks

methods.name: A

methods.description:
This will compare two javascript values of possibly different types.
It will tell you which one is greater than the other by returning:

 - -1 if the first is smaller than the second,
 - 0 if both are equal,
 - 1 if the first is greater than the second.

The order is calculated based on `Ember.ORDER_DEFINITION`, if types are different.
In case they have the same type an appropriate comparison for this type is made.

 ```javascript
 Ember.compare('hello', 'hello');  // 0
 Ember.compare('abc', 'dfg');      // -1
 Ember.compare(2, 1);              // 1
 ```
methods.name: compare

params.name: v
params.description: First value to compare

params.name: w
params.description: Second value to compare

return.description: -1 if v < w, 0 if v = w and 1 if v > w.

methods.description:
Creates a clone of the passed object. This function can take just about
any type of object and create a clone of it, including primitive values
(which are not actually cloned because they are immutable).

If the passed object implements the `copy()` method, then this function
will simply call that method and return the result. Please see
`Ember.Copyable` for further details.
methods.name: copy

params.name: obj
params.description: The object to clone

params.name: deep
params.description: If true, a deep copy of the object is made

methods.description:
Compares two objects, returning true if they are logically equal. This is
a deeper comparison than a simple triple equal. For sets it will compare the
internal objects. For any other object that implements `isEqual()` it will
respect that method.

```javascript
Ember.isEqual('hello', 'hello');  // true
Ember.isEqual(1, 2);              // false
Ember.isEqual([4, 2], [4, 2]);    // false
```
methods.name: isEqual

params.name: a
params.description: first object to compare

params.name: b
params.description: second object to compare

methods.description:
This method allows other Ember modules to register injection helpers for a
given container type. Helpers are exported to the `inject` namespace as the
container type itself.
methods.name: createInjectionHelper

params.name: type
params.description: The container type the helper will inject

params.name: validator
params.description: A validation callback that is executed at mixin-time

methods.description:
Validation function that runs per-type validation functions once for each
injected type encountered.
methods.name: validatePropertyInjections

params.name: factory
params.description: The factory object

methods.description:
Returns true if the passed object is an array or Array-like.

Ember Array Protocol:

  - the object has an objectAt property
  - the object is a native Array
  - the object is an Object, and has a length property

Unlike `Ember.typeOf` this method returns true even if the passed object is
not formally array but appears to be array-like (i.e. implements `Ember.Array`)

```javascript
Ember.isArray();                                          // false
Ember.isArray([]);                                        // true
Ember.isArray(Ember.ArrayProxy.create({ content: [] }));  // true
```
methods.name: isArray

params.name: obj
params.description: The object to test

return.description: true if the passed object is an array or Array-like

methods.description:
Returns a consistent type for the passed item.

Use this instead of the built-in `typeof` to get the type of an item.
It will return the same result across all browsers and includes a bit
more detail. Here is what will be returned:

    | Return Value  | Meaning                                              |
    |---------------|------------------------------------------------------|
    | 'string'      | String primitive or String object.                   |
    | 'number'      | Number primitive or Number object.                   |
    | 'boolean'     | Boolean primitive or Boolean object.                 |
    | 'null'        | Null value                                           |
    | 'undefined'   | Undefined value                                      |
    | 'function'    | A function                                           |
    | 'array'       | An instance of Array                                 |
    | 'regexp'      | An instance of RegExp                                |
    | 'date'        | An instance of Date                                  |
    | 'class'       | An Ember class (created using Ember.Object.extend()) |
    | 'instance'    | An Ember object instance                             |
    | 'error'       | An instance of the Error object                      |
    | 'object'      | A JavaScript object not inheriting from Ember.Object |

Examples:

```javascript
Ember.typeOf();                       // 'undefined'
Ember.typeOf(null);                   // 'null'
Ember.typeOf(undefined);              // 'undefined'
Ember.typeOf('michael');              // 'string'
Ember.typeOf(new String('michael'));  // 'string'
Ember.typeOf(101);                    // 'number'
Ember.typeOf(new Number(101));        // 'number'
Ember.typeOf(true);                   // 'boolean'
Ember.typeOf(new Boolean(true));      // 'boolean'
Ember.typeOf(Ember.makeArray);        // 'function'
Ember.typeOf([1, 2, 90]);             // 'array'
Ember.typeOf(/abc/);                  // 'regexp'
Ember.typeOf(new Date());             // 'date'
Ember.typeOf(Ember.Object.extend());  // 'class'
Ember.typeOf(Ember.Object.create());  // 'instance'
Ember.typeOf(new Error('teamocil'));  // 'error'

// 'normal' JavaScript object
Ember.typeOf({ a: 'b' });             // 'object'
```
methods.name: typeOf

params.name: item
params.description: the item to check

methods.description: Alias for jQuery

events.name: onerror

params.name: error
params.description: the error object

properties.description:
Debug parameter you can turn on. This will log all bindings that fire to
the console. This should be disabled in production code. Note that you
can also enable this from the console or temporarily.
properties.name: LOG_BINDINGS

properties.description:
The hash of environment variables used to control various configuration
settings. To specify your own or override default settings, add the
desired properties to a global hash named `EmberENV` (or `ENV` for
backwards compatibility with earlier versions of Ember). The `EmberENV`
hash must be created before loading Ember.
properties.name: ENV

properties.description:
Determines whether Ember should add to `Array`, `Function`, and `String`
native object prototypes, a few extra methods in order to provide a more
friendly API.

We generally recommend leaving this option set to true however, if you need
to turn it off, you can add the configuration property
`EXTEND_PROTOTYPES` to `EmberENV` and set it to `false`.

Note, when disabled (the default configuration for Ember Addons), you will
instead have to access all methods and functions from the Ember
namespace.
properties.name: EXTEND_PROTOTYPES

properties.description:
The `LOG_STACKTRACE_ON_DEPRECATION` property, when true, tells Ember to log
a full stack trace during deprecation warnings.
properties.name: LOG_STACKTRACE_ON_DEPRECATION

properties.description:
The `SHIM_ES5` property, when true, tells Ember to add ECMAScript 5 Array
shims to older browsers.
properties.name: SHIM_ES5

properties.description:
The `LOG_VERSION` property, when true, tells Ember to log versions of all
dependent libraries in use.
properties.name: LOG_VERSION

properties.description: Prefix used for guids through out Ember.
properties.name: GUID_PREFIX

properties.description:
A unique key used to assign guids and other private metadata to objects.
If you inspect an object in your browser debugger you will often see these.
They can be safely ignored.

On browsers that support it, these properties are added with enumeration
disabled so they won't show up when you iterate over your properties.
properties.name: GUID_KEY

properties.description:
Defines the hash of localized strings for the current language. Used by
the `Ember.String.loc()` helper. To localize, add string values to this
hash.
properties.name: STRINGS

properties.description:
Global hash of shared templates. This will automatically be populated
by the build tools so that you can store your Handlebars templates in
separate files that get loaded into JavaScript at buildtime.
properties.name: TEMPLATES
